summary_md: Recorded and verified core definitions and elementary bounds for the hunters–rabbit evasion number h(G). Proved schedule verification equivalence (S_1..S_t wins iff R_t=∅ with R_{i+1}=N(R_i)\S_{i+1}), subgraph monotonicity, lower bounds h(G)≥δ(G) and hence ≥ degeneracy(G), and the upper bound h(G)≤τ(G) (capture by shooting a minimum vertex cover twice). Determined exact values h(K_n)=n−1 and h(K_{p,q})=min{p,q}; cycles: C_3,C_4 have h=2 and an explicit 4-round 2-hunter schedule shows h(C_5)≤2 (odd cycles require time-varying schedules). Algorithmically: fast NO filters (degeneracy>k or ω(G)≥k+2) and fast YES via τ(G)≤k, but NP-membership is unresolved because winning schedules may need unbounded length. Open targets: prove h(C_n)=2, classify h(G)=1, and investigate h(G)≤tw(G) or an n^{O(k)} separator DP. Citations: proofs.md; research notes.
one_line_summary: Verified basic bounds and exact values; C5 2-hunter schedule; open: cycles, k=1, treewidth/DP.
highlights: Schedule verification: S_1..S_t wins iff R_t=∅ with R_{i+1}=N(R_i)\S_{i+1}.
Monotonicity and lower bounds: h(H)≤h(G); h(G)≥δ(G) and hence ≥ degeneracy(G); K_{s,t} gives h≥min{s,t}.
Upper bound: h(G)≤τ(G) (shoot a minimum vertex cover twice) — yields fast YES via FPT vertex-cover.
Exact values: h(K_n)=n−1 and h(K_{p,q})=min{p,q}. Cycles: C_3,C_4 have h=2; explicit 4-round 2-hunter schedule shows h(C_5)≤2.
Algorithmic filters: fast NO if degeneracy>k or ω(G)≥k+2. NP-membership of the decision problem is unsettled due to potentially exponential schedule length.
Corrections recorded: h(K_n) corrected to n−1; 1 hunter can win on P_4 (conjectured h(P_n)=1); fixed antipodal-pair schedules fail on odd cycles.
next_questions: Prove h(C_n)=2 for all n≥3 and give a constructive schedule.
Resolve k=1: characterize graphs with h(G)=1 (is it exactly forests?).
Investigate whether h(G)≤tw(G) or design a separator-based DP that yields n^{O(k)} recognition.
